NCBI_TAXONOMY_ID:.description: The branch of science concerned with classification, especially of organisms on the basis of shared characteristics

SPECIES.description: The species is the fundamental category of taxonomic classification, ranking below a genus or subgenus

N-GLYCOSYLATION.description: In O-glycosylation, sugars are attached to oxygen, typically on serine or threonine, but also on tyrosine or non-canonical amino acids such as hydroxylysine & hydroxyproline.

INTERACTING_GLYCAN.tooltip: Click to highlight multiple selections for Glycosylated Amino Acid
INTERACTING_GLYCAN.description: Amino acids are organic compounds containing amine (-NH2) and carboxyl (-COOH) functional groups, along with a side chain (R group) specific to each amino acid

PEPTIDE.description: A compound consisting of two or more amino acids linked in a chain, the carboxyl group of each acid being joined to the amino group of the next by a bond of the type -OC-NH-

POSITION.description: Amino acid residue position in the protein sequence

GLYCAN_TYPE.tooltip: Click to select a Glycan Type
GLYCAN_TYPE.description: The classification of glycan based on the nature of the sugar–peptide bond and the oligosaccharide attached. Eg. N-linked glycans, O-linked glycans, C-linked

MONOISOTOPIC_MASS.tooltip: Use the sliders to select a Monoisotopic Mass range for your protein(s)
MONOISOTOPIC_MASS.description: The monoisotopic mass is the sum of the masses of the atoms in a molecule using the unbound, ground-state, rest mass of the principal (most abundant) isotope for each element instead of the isotopic average mass in Daltons

GENE_NAME.tooltip: Enter the Name of the Gene encoding your protein
GENE_NAME.description: Name/Symbol of the gene officially assigned by the HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC)

PATHWAY.tooltip: Enter a Pathway ID from KEGG or Reactome
PATHWAY.description: A biological pathway is a series of actions among molecules in a cell that leads to a certain product or a change in the cell. Such a pathway can trigger the assembly of new molecules, such as a fat or protein. Pathways can also turn genes on and off, or spur a cell to move

GLYCAN_SUBTYPE.tooltip: Click to select a Glycan Subtype
GLYCAN_SUBTYPE.description: Subclassifcation of Glycan types - The three different types of N-linked glycans are high mannose, complex and hybrid and for the O-linked glycans they are Core 1,2,3,4,5,6

C-GLYCOSYLATION.description: In N-glycosylation, sugars are attached to nitrogen, typically on the amide side-chain of asparagine. N-linked glycans are almost always attached to the nitrogen atom of an asparagine (Asn) side chain that is present as a part of Asn–X–Ser/Thr consensus sequence, where X is any amino acid except proline (Pro)

UNIPROT_ACCESSION.tooltip: Enter the UniProt Accession of a glycoprotein that bears your glycan(s) Protein: Enter the UniProt Accession of your protein (see https://www.uniprot.org/)
UNIPROT_ACCESSION.description: A unique identifier assigned to a isoform chosen to be the canonical sequence in UniProt database. The identifier is composed of primary accession number which consists of 6-10 alphanumeric charaters, followed by a dash and a number

GLYCOSYLATED_AMINO.tooltip: Click to select Glycosylation Evidence Type

END POSITION.description: End position of the altered amino acid in the sequence.

PEPTIDE_SEQUENCE.tooltip: Click to select Sequence Type and enter a Protein or Peptide Sequence
PEPTIDE_SEQUENCE.description: The sequence of the amino acids of the protein or peptide

GLYCAN_MOTIF.tooltip: Enter a Glycan Motif comprising part of your glycan(s)
GLYCAN_MOTIF.description: A “motif” refers to a substructure that appears in multiple glycans including O and N glycans.

P-GLYCOSYLATION.tooltip: Enter the GlyTouCan Accession of a glycan that is covalently attached to or non-covalently binds to your protein(s)

CROSS_REFERENCES.description: A reference to other database's id/accession to link their related knowledge together; that is a cross-reference to the id/accession of the database under study.

ORGANISM.tooltip: Glycan: Click to select an Organism that makes your glycan(s) Protein: Click to select an Organism that makes your protein(s)
ORGANISM.description: An individual animal, plant, or single-celled life form

NUMBER_OF_SUGARS.tooltip: Use the sliders to select a Number of Sugars range for your protein(s)

PROTEIN_NAME.tooltip: Enter the Name of your protein
PROTEIN_NAME.description: Protein name in a database that allows unambiguous identification of a protein.

WURCS.description: Web3 Unique Representation of Carbohydrate Structures (WURCS) as a new linear notation for representing carbohydrates for the Semantic Web

SEQUENCE.description: Altered amino acid resulting from mutated nucleotide

RESIDUE.description: When two or more amino acids combine to form a peptide, the elements of water are removed, and what remains of each amino acid is called an amino-acid residue

CHEMICAL _MASS:.tooltip: Use the sliders to select a Chemical Mass range for your protein(s)

GLYCOCT.description: The sequence format based on a connection table approach, instead of a linear encoding scheme, to describe the carbohydrate sequences, with a controlled vocabulary to name monosaccharides, adopting IUPAC rules to generate a consistent, machine-readable nomenclature

BIOSYNTHETIC_ENZYME.tooltip: Enter the Gene Name of an enzyme that particpates in the biosynthesis of your glycan(s)
BIOSYNTHETIC_ENZYME.description: Biosynthetic enzymes are enzymes involved in metabolism pathways that convert and modify simple compounds to complex coumpounds and macromolecules. In this case biosynthetic enzymes refer to the Glycosyltransferases.

ISOFORMS.description: Any of two or more functionally similar proteins that have a similar but not identical amino acid sequence and are either encoded by different genes or by RNA transcripts from the same gene which have had different exons

START POSITION.description: Starting position of the altered amino acid in the sequence.

O-GLYCOSYLATION.description: In P-glycosylation, sugars are attached to phosphorus on a phosphoserine

TISSUE.description: The title of the research article published in the journal
TISSUE.example: Hepatocyte growth factor is linked by O-glycosylated oligosaccharide on the alpha chain.

IUPAC.description: Representation of carbohydrate structures in the The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) notation

CHROMOSOME.description: In the nucleus of each cell, the DNA molecule is packaged into thread-like structures called chromosomes. Each chromosome is made up of DNA tightly coiled many times around proteins called histones that support its structure.

S-GLYCOSYLATION.description: In C-glycosylation, sugars are attached directly to carbon, such as in the addition of mannose to tryptophan.

REFSEQ_ACCESSION.tooltip: Enter the RefSeq Accession of your protein (see https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/refseq/)
REFSEQ_ACCESSION.description: A distinct accession number format assigned to RefSeq record that begins with two characters followed by an underscore in the NCBI RefSeq database

SIGNIFICANT.description: Significant differential expression of the gene that can be either "Yes" or "No", depending on whether p is greater than the FDR after Benjamini-Hochberg correction for multiple-testing (Default FDR=0.1)

DIGITAL_SEQUENCE.description: The carbohydrate sequence of the glycan structure in GlycoCT, IUPAC, WURCS format

PMID.description: In S-glycosylation, a beta-GlcNAc is attached to the sulfur atom of a cysteine residue

GLYTOUCAN_ACCESSION.tooltip: Enter complete or partial GlyTouCan Accession of your glycan (see https://glytoucan.org/)
GLYTOUCAN_ACCESSION.description: Unique accessions assigned to the registered glycan structures in GlyTouCan database

KEYWORDS.description: A group of cells that act together to carry out a specific function in the body.
